Issues.Title: Binding doesn't update when DataContext changes if overridden Object.Equals is true
Issues.Body:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/608757/binding-doesnt-update-when-datacontext-changes-if.html)._ ---

There is a bug in BindingExpression.OnDataContextChanged when the DataContext object overrides Object.Equals and the new context 'equals' the old one. The call to Object.Equals(DataItem, newItem) should be Object.ReferenceEquals(DataItem, newItem). See the attached example project.

bindingbug.zip

We have directed your feedback to the appropriate engineering team for further evaluation. The team will review the feedback and notify you about the next steps.

We set priority based on severity, similar reports, and the overall impact on users and scenarios. We've also learned that reports without fresh activity could indicate that the problem isn't a problem anymore. One of our goals is to give you more transparency around these decisions as resolving every problem that gets reported isn't always possible. Your feedback is essential for helping us decide what needs the most attention, so please keep upvoting and commenting if you think that we need to make this a higher priority . --- ### Original Solutions (no solutions)

Issues.Title: BitmapFrame.Create uses ImageCache even if BitMapCreateOptions.IgnoreImageCache is passed
Issues.Body:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/606870/bitmapframecreate-uses-imagecache-even-if-bitmapcr.html)._ --- e.g. in the following usage: BitmapFrame source = BitmapFrame.Create(new Uri(filePath), System.Windows.Media.Imaging.BitmapCreateOptions.IgnoreImageCache, BitmapCacheOption.None); BitmapFrame still uses ImageCache, inspite of BitmapCreateOptions.IgnoreImageCache option. --- ### Original Comments #### Feedback Bot on 6/14/2019, 04:38 PM:

Issues.Title: System.Xaml platform independence
Issues.Body:
I was looking at using System.Xaml to serialize some state in an application. My usage is completely unrelated to windows and UI components. System.Xaml appears to be almost entirely platform agnostic, except for one reference to System.Windows.Extensions. As far as I can tell, the only type consumed in that library is System.Xaml.Permissions.XamlAccessLevel, which itself doesn't have any platform specific dependencies. If it was possible to move that XamlAccessLevel type into System.Xaml, and "forward" it from System.Windows.Extensions, that could make System.Xaml completely platform agnostic (as far as I can tell).

Would platform independence be a desirable property for System.Xaml to have?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "System.Xaml platform independence" (#3543)

Issues.Title: Ask-Mode: [release/5.0-rc2] Custom intermediate output paths shouldn't break markup compilation
Issues.Body:
**Original PR:** 

https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/pull/3120

**Customer Impact:**

Setting custom output paths in a WPF project breaks markup compilation, a necessary requirement for many customers.  We continue to get new issues related to this problem.

**Risk:** 

This only affects markup compilation in WPF projects that use custom paths.  There are no changes to the WPF runtime.   

**Testing:**

Unit testing of the path calculation, .NET Core and .NET Framework markup compilation targeting .NET Core and .NET Framework, and all of the current issues root-caused to this problem that contain repro projects.

**Regression:**

No.

Issues.Title: User Input Simulation API
Issues.Body:
## Requested API

Support for simulating various types of user input:
* mouse movement and clicks
* keyboard key presses (this is already possible in Winforms)
* touchscreen finger commands
* stylus actions

## Motivation

WPF is very much still a popular framework for Windows desktop development, despite there being plenty of alternatives such as [UWP](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/uwp/), [Avalonia](http://avaloniaui.net/) and [Electron.NET](https://github.com/ElectronNET/Electron.NET) to name a few. Therefore, many developers may be developing touchscreen applications in WPF to scale to support more modern devices.

If there was a way to manipulate the mouse, keyboard and touch functionalities, developers could simulate end-user decisions, which could be useful for demo purposes or even for testing purposes. One could see if a certain chain of end-user decisions leads to a desired outcome. Moreover, simulating keyboard inputs can also be useful to create a customizable on-screen touchscreen keyboard, which simply does not exist as a standard control in WPF.

## The *InputSimulatorCore* NuGet package

There is this NuGet package called [Input Simulator Core](https://github.com/cwevers/InputSimulatorCore) that lets developers simulate keyboard and mouse inputs. It was originally developed to create a touchscreen keyboard. However, it is not being maintained anymore and the input simulations only work on Windows devices. Given that WPF also only works on Windows, that is admittedly not much of an issue. But seeing recent developments at Microsoft with cross-platform application development frameworks such as .NET MAUI, support for user input could provide major advantages for developers working on all platforms.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "User Input Simulation API" (#3539)

Issues.Title: Provide a NuGet package for UIAutomation assemblies
Issues.Body:
The current implementation of the UIAutomation assemblies is tied to the `Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App` framework.  This makes it difficult to use for custom UI toolkits not based on WPF or WinForms and requires an undesirable dependencies on WPF native libraries.

Use case:  for custom UI toolkits that want to support accessibility there needs to be a way to use the UIAutomation assemblies.  For .NET Framework these libraries are readily available as part of the framework.  For .NET Core in order to reference these assemblies one must add a framework reference to `Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App` however this brings in many unneeded assembly references (including WinForms, WPF etc...) which aren't needed when using a custom UI toolkit.

The ideal solution would be a nuget package that:

1. for .NET Framework includes references to the assemblies in .NET framework 
2. for .NET Core includes just the required UIAutomation assemblies need to implement accessibility.

In fact our current solution to this is a hacked together nuget package that does just this - [see here](https://github.com/toptensoftware/uiautomation).  Unfortunately it also needs to bring in a dependency on PresentationNative_cor3.dll.

One solution suggested by the UIAutomation team was to generate our own copy of Primary Interop Assembly using the tlbimp tool however if a toolkit has already implemented accessibility using the UIAutomation classes in .NET Framework this means considerable additional work porting to this different API.

While this is a fairly niche requirement, any UI toolkit (eg: AvaloniaUI) wanting to target .NET Core will face a similar problem.  If Microsoft could provide a standalone nuget package that provides the UIAutomation assemblies required to implement accessibility this would be a great help to anyone implementing custom UI toolkits.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Provide a NuGet package for UIAutomation assemblies" (#3536)

Issues.Title: WPF application targeting .NET 4.8 with SDK Microsoft.NET.Sdk fails to build on 5.0.100-rc.1.20454.5
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 5.0.100-rc.1.20454.5
* Windows version: 2004
 
 **Problem description:**

'dotnet build' when targeting 4.8 with Microsoft.NET.Sdk fails to build.  SDK must be changed to Microsoft.NET.Sdk.WindowsDesktop. 
 
 **Actual behavior:** <!-- callstack for crashes / exceptions -->

A large number of missing reference errors.
 
 **Expected behavior:**

The project builds when targeting 5.0-windows, but not 4.8, or 4.8-windows.
 
 **Minimal repro:**

dotnet new wpf
dotnet build 
observe 5.0-windows builds
edit the .csproj to target 4.8 (net4.8)
dotnet build
observe that the build fails

```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>WinExe</OutputType>
    <!--
    <TargetFramework>net5.0-windows</TargetFramework> - SUCCEEDS
    <TargetFrameworks>net4.8;net5.0-windows</TargetFrameworks> - FAILS
    <TargetFramework>net4.8-windows</TargetFramework> - FAILS
    -->
    <TargetFramework>net4.8</TargetFramework>
    <UseWPF>true</UseWPF>
  </PropertyGroup>
</Project
```

Issues.Title: XPS documents in .NET Core can't be opened
Issues.Body:
Besides the [impersonation limitation I reported earlier](https://github.com/dotnet/core/issues/5021) we have also found that XPS documents coming from a virtual printer can't be opened in .NET Core. 

We first have to extract the XPS files, combine all part files to a single file and then create the XPS file again. Then we can open an XPS file in .NET Core. 

Is this by design or a bug? 

Because we don't have to do this in .NET Full Framework.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "XPS documents in .NET Core can't be opened" (#3546)
